newsitem.title: UK: INTERVIEW-Tarmac says savings to boost H2.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW-Tarmac says savings to boost H2.

text.p: UK building group Tarmac Plc, which slumped to a 58.3 million stg half year loss after taking a 65 million restructuring hit, said on Tuesday it expected cost savings to start boosting results in the second half.

Tarmac announced that it expected savings of 35 million a year as a result of its asset swap with housebuilder Wimpey Plc earlier this year. Although this failed to impact on the interim results, Neville Sims, chief executive told Reuters: "There will be increased benefit in the second half."
Sims expected part of the 18 million of cost savings from the building materials business to feed through in the last six months.
But on the construction side, he warned: "There will not be much benefit before next year. You must add the full cost savings against next year's results."
Under the asset swap, Tarmac took on Wimpey's construction and aggregates arms in return for its housebuilding business.
Tarmac's chief revealed that the total number of jobs lost under its restructuring was 1,400. Of that total, 300 remain to be axed.
The job loss programme will be completed by the end of the year. Costs attached to this programme of redundancies account for the bulk of the charge.
Stripping out the 65 million stg restructuring charge, underlying pretax profits were still weak at 6.7 million versus 29.1 million last year.
The dividend was frozen at 3.0 pence per share.
Tarmac blamed the profit downturn on poor market conditions and bad winter weather which delayed projects across Europe.
That region remains a tough one for the group, with difficulties in the French market earning particular note.
